required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Zenith(R) Low Profile AAA Endovascular Graft Clinical Study
clinical_study.official_title: Evaluation of the Safety and Effectiveness of the Zenith(R) Low Profile AAA Endovascular Graft

brief_summary.textblock: The Zenith® Low Profile AAA Endovascular Graft Clinical Study is a clinical trial approved by US FDA to study the safety and effectiveness of the Zenith® Low Profile AAA Endovascular Graft to treat abdominal aortic, aorto-iliac, and iliac aneurysms.

primary_outcome.description: MAE is defined as any occurrence of all-cause death, Q-wave myocardial infarction (MI), renal failure requiring dialysis, paralysis, stroke, bowel ischemia, or re-intubation.

Device success at 12-month is defined as: Technical Success (successful access of the aneurysm site, deployment of the graft in the intended location, and patency of the graft at the time of deployment completion intra-operatively), and freedom from the following at 12 months: Type I or type III endoleaks requiring re-intervention, Aneurysm rupture or conversion to open surgical repair, and Aneurysm enlargement greater than 0.5 cm.

intervention.intervention_name: Zenith(R) Low Profile AAA Endovascular Graft
intervention.description: The Zenith(R) Low Profile AAA Endovascular Graft and ancillary components are indicated for the endovascular treatment of patients with abdominal aortic, aorto-iliac, or iliac aneurysms having morphology suitable for endovascular repair.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Abdominal aortic, aortoiliac, and iliac aneurysms of appropriate size
- Vessels suitable for endovascular access and aneurysm repair
Exclusion Criteria:
- Less than 18 years of age
- Inability or refusal to give informed consent
- Disease considerations that would compromise patient safety or study outcomes
- Unsuitable arterial anatomy

facility.name: University of California, San Francisco, Div. Vascular Surgery and San Francisco VAMC
Yale New Haven School of Med., Dept. of Vascular Surgery
University of Rochester, Strong Memorial Hospital
Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania

group.title: Zenith® Low Profile AAA Endovascular Graft
group.description: The Zenith® Low Profile AAA Endovascular Graft and ancillary components are indicated for the endovascular treatment of patients with abdominal aortic, aorto-iliac, or iliac aneurysms having morphology suitable for endovascular repair.

group.title: Zenith® Low Profile AAA Endovascular Graft
group.description: The Zenith® Low Profile AAA Endovascular Graft and ancillary components are indicated for the endovascular treatment of patients with abdominal aortic, aorto-iliac, or iliac aneurysms having morphology suitable for endovascular repair.

outcome.title: Patients With Major Adverse Events (MAE)
outcome.description: MAE is defined as any occurrence of all-cause death, Q-wave myocardial infarction (MI), renal failure requiring dialysis, paralysis, stroke, bowel ischemia, or re-intubation.
outcome.population: 1 patient experienced a re-intubation, which was adjudicated by the CEC as not related to AAA repair (related to a pre-existing condition).

group.title: Zenith® Low Profile AAA Endovascular Graft
group.description: The Zenith® Low Profile AAA Endovascular Graft and ancillary components are indicated for the endovascular treatment of patients with abdominal aortic, aorto-iliac, or iliac aneurysms having morphology suitable for endovascular repair.

measure.title: Patients With Major Adverse Events (MAE)
measure.description: MAE is defined as any occurrence of all-cause death, Q-wave myocardial infarction (MI), renal failure requiring dialysis, paralysis, stroke, bowel ischemia, or re-intubation.
measure.population: 1 patient experienced a re-intubation, which was adjudicated by the CEC as not related to AAA repair (related to a pre-existing condition).

analysis.groups_desc: Null hypothesis: The 30-day Freedom from MAE for patients treated with the Zenith® Low Profile AAA Endovascular Graft does not meet the performance goal (88%).

outcome.title: Patients With Device Failures
outcome.description: Device success at 12-month is defined as: Technical Success (successful access of the aneurysm site, deployment of the graft in the intended location, and patency of the graft at the time of deployment completion intra-operatively), and freedom from the following at 12 months: Type I or type III endoleaks requiring re-intervention, Aneurysm rupture or conversion to open surgical repair, and Aneurysm enlargement greater than 0.5 cm.
outcome.population: There were 5 patients died, and 2 patients withdrew.

group.title: Zenith® Low Profile AAA Endovascular Graft
group.description: The Zenith® Low Profile AAA Endovascular Graft and ancillary components are indicated for the endovascular treatment of patients with abdominal aortic, aorto-iliac, or iliac aneurysms having morphology suitable for endovascular repair.

measure.title: Patients With Device Failures
measure.description: Device success at 12-month is defined as: Technical Success (successful access of the aneurysm site, deployment of the graft in the intended location, and patency of the graft at the time of deployment completion intra-operatively), and freedom from the following at 12 months: Type I or type III endoleaks requiring re-intervention, Aneurysm rupture or conversion to open surgical repair, and Aneurysm enlargement greater than 0.5 cm.
measure.population: There were 5 patients died, and 2 patients withdrew.

analysis.groups_desc: Null hypothesis: The 12-month device success for patients treated with the Zenith® Low Profile AAA Endovascular Graft does not meet the performance goal (84%).

group.title: Zenith® Low Profile AAA Endovascular Graft
group.description: The Zenith® Low Profile AAA Endovascular Graft and ancillary components are indicated for the endovascular treatment of patients with abdominal aortic, aorto-iliac, or iliac aneurysms having morphology suitable for endovascular repair.

event.sub_title: Low hemoglobin (6.9) transfused 2 units packed red blood cells (PRBC)
Arrhythmia requiring intervention or new treatment
Cardiac event involving arrest, resuscitation, or balloon pump
Chest pain requiring hospital admission and cardiac catheterization
Upgrade of an implantable cardioverter (ICD) to a BIV ICD as well as implantation of a new ICD lead
Acute diverticulitis in the descending colon
Complication requiring return to operating room (OR)
Perineal wound discharge after resection of rectum
Fall resulting in rib fracture and closed fracture of acetabulum
Left hip pain due to degeneration of hip joint

category.title: Neoplasms benign, malignant and unspecified (incl cysts and polyps)

event.sub_title: T1 grade 3 urothelial carcinoma of the bladder
Left partial third nerve palsy. Diplopia.
Serum creatinine rise > 30% above baseline resulting in a persistent value > 2.0 mg/dl
Urinary tract infection (UTI) requiring antibiotic treatment
Acute chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) exacerbation
Increased dyspnea leading to new diagnosis of sleep apnea
New 7.7 cm right upper lung zone mass concerning for neoplasm
Pulmonary event requiring tracheostomy or chest tube
Shortness of breath with right swollen extremity
Clotted left superficial femoral artery (LSFA) to post-tibial bypass graft
Embolization resulting in tissue loss or requiring intervention
Low systolic blood pressure: 70 recorded on 10/14/09
Patient became hypotensive upon anesthesia induction - sustained

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: The only disclosure restriction on the PI is that the sponsor can review results communications prior to public release and can embargo communications regarding trial results for a period that is more than 60 days but less than or equal to 180 days. The sponsor cannot require changes to the communication and cannot extend the embargo.

point_of_contact.name_or_title: Scott Snyder, PhD, Director of Clinical Science & Biostatistics
